docs.lead_paragraph: Speaker Newt Gingrich proposed an effort today to improve health care for veterans, saying that those who risked their lives for the nation should have access to the best medicine it can offer. Mr. Gingrich, speaking to 5,000 people at a convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars here, said he would work with veterans' advocates to create a commission on setting new health care standards over the next two years.

headline.main: Gingrich Urges 'Best' Health Care for Veterans

docs.abstract: Speaker Newt Gingrich, speaking to 5,000 people at convention of Veterans of Foreign Wars in Salt Lake City, Utah, proposes effort to improve health care for veterans; says he will work with veterans' advocates to create commission on setting new health care standards over next two years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The worst day for Thomas Hargrove was the day the guerrillas mistakenly killed the cow. That blunder sent the leader of the tiny band that had kidnapped Mr. Hargrove into a rage. He stomped around the encampment in the cold, wet mountains of Colombia, shooting at rocks and trees, his mind fuzzy with whisky and cocaine. Still furious, the guerrilla leader came up behind Mr. Hargrove, then in his early 50's and in charge of communications at an international research center near Cali, and pressed the steel barrel of his rifle against the American's skull. He pulled back a couple of inches and fired -- into the sky.

headline.main: Peace of Mind for Global Executives
headline.kicker: A Hedge Against Abductions On the Rise

docs.abstract: Growing number of small businesses are signing up for special kind of insurance policy: coverage against kidnapping; insurance is intended for expatriate executives, corporate road warriors and even those at home office; wealthy foreigners, who are even more attractive targets than American executives, are also signing up; policies not only provide money for ransom, but also pay for such things as costly fees of kidnap negotiators--which can run to $15,000 a week--and follow-up psychiatric treatment for victims and their families; kidnapping of Thomas Hargrove by Colombian guerrillas in 1994 and his release in August 1995 discussed; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was the inevitable bad day, a few weeks after Arthur Ashe died, when Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe needed to talk to somebody, somebody who would understand what it was like to be the widow of a celebrated man who died far too young. ''There was a swirl of events, a lot on my shoulders,'' she recalled. ''There were a lot of people coming at me from a lot of directions. When I searched my mind, one person came to my mind.''
docs.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times columm discusses bond between Arthur Ashe's widow Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe and Rachel Robinson, widow of Jackie Robinson; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Merril Eisenbud, an environmental scientist who was the first health and safety chief of the United States Atomic Energy Commission and the first head of New York City's Environmental Protection Agency, died on Friday at the Carolina Meadows retirement community in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 82 and a former resident of Sterling Forest, N.Y. The cause was leukemia, his family said.

headline.main: Merril Eisenbud, 82, Safety Expert Known for Work on Atomic Energy

docs.abstract: Merril Eisenbud, environmental scientist who was first health and safety chief of US Atomic Energy Commission and first head of New York City's Environmental Protection Agency, died on Aug 15 at age 82 (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a weary-eyed Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, held a news conference at 1 A.M. today to trumpet his union's agreement with the United Parcel Service, he said what all of organized labor was waiting to hear. The settlement, in which the teamsters won most of what they wanted on pensions, pay and limiting the use of part-time workers, will be as much of a boon to labor, he said, as the failed air traffic controllers' strike of 1981 was a bust.

headline.main: A Victory for Labor, but How Far Will It Go?
headline.kicker: CONCLUDING THE U.P.S. STRIKE: NEWS ANALYSIS

docs.abstract: Analysis of implications for organized labor of teamsters' union settlement with United Parcel Service; labor leaders, who solidly backed union, hail victory on pensions, wages and limiting use of part-time workers as important for organized labor; many economists and business leaders doubt accord will have much affect on other labor settlements; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaving a trail of confused curbside customers in their wake, several hundred yellow cabs streamed past fares and down Broadway yesterday afternoon, protesting the Giuliani administration's stepped-up enforcement of taxi regulations and demanding health benefits from the city. The Lease Drivers Coalition, which represents 850 drivers and organized the protest, said it drew nearly 6,000 cabs; the police estimated 350 to 400. The parade of cars started in the East Village, made its way to Broadway and congregated at City Hall, where many of the cabs dispersed.

headline.main: Cabdrivers Pass Up Fares in Protest Against Tickets

docs.abstract: Several hundred New York City taxicab drivers stream past fares, protesting Giuliani administration's stepped-up enforcement of taxi regulations and demanding health benefits from city; demonstration drive is organized by Lease Drivers Coalition; it starts in East Village and ends at City Hall, where many of cabs disperse; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Labor leaders exulted yesterday in the settlement of the 15-day strike at United Parcel Service, for understandable reasons. The teamsters won most of their demands -- for wage increases, pension protections and especially for upgrading thousands of jobs from part time to full time. More than that, the union dramatized what it sees as a pernicious trend, the growing reliance of companies on two-tiered work forces in which significant numbers of employees receive lower wages or benefits. It was far from clear, however, that the labor movement will be able to build on its victory to help workers elsewhere who have felt left out by the extraordinary economic boom of recent years. President Clinton and Labor Secretary Alexis Herman played a constructive role in pushing for a settlement of a strike that had begun to hurt many businesses. But one of the most remarkable facts about the walkout at the world's largest package delivery company was the extent of public support generated by the 185,000 strikers. Some surveys showed that Americans supported them by a margin of 2 to 1. Mr. Clinton was probably correct in warning that public approval might soon reach its limits, but news of widespread sympathy for the strikers galvanized people on the picket lines and no doubt contributed to United Parcel's decision to make significant concessions.
docs.abstract: Editorial on settlement of teamsters' strike against United Parcel Service questions whether labor movement will be able to build on victory to help workers elsewhere; cites public support for strikers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago Dixie Redmond thought every tomato was red and round and hard as a baseball. But that was before she heard of heirloom tomatoes, before she met tomato people in cyberspace, before she dug up her backyard in Hampden, Me., to plant 21 varieties with names like Sun Gold and Aunt Ruby's German Green.

headline.main: The Tomato, Singing Its Siren Song

docs.abstract: Article discusses growing popularity of growing different varieties of tomatoes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just when it looked as if Big Tobacco had had a change of heart, along comes a reminder of the industry's arrogance. Exercising their diligently purchased Congressional influence, tobacco companies got Congress to insert a $50 billion giveaway into the tax-cut legislation enacted last month. The credit was specifically designed to offset the $368 billion the industry agreed to pay to settle anti-tobacco litigation in 40 states earlier this year. Even worse, it was tucked away in such an obscure corner of the legislation that many members of Congress say they were unaware it was there. Clearly, Congress must now wake up and repeal the tax credit as part of any tobacco settlement it approves.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Congress to repeal $50 billion tax credit granted tobacco companies in tax-cut legislation, as part of any settlement it approves in class-action suit against industry (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In these financially strapped times for the District of Columbia, this was a rare moment for celebration. Officials from a group of private health care organizations gathered at a city clinic the other day to announce programs that would provide medical insurance for 1,000 children. Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was the scheduled guest speaker, but he had not arrived for the start of the ceremony. ''We'll go ahead, anyway,'' said a woman at the lectern. ''It's too hot to wait.'' He never made it.

headline.main: Congress Whittles Away Power of Capital's Mayor

docs.abstract: Marion S Barry, mayor of Washington, DC, for 15 of last 19 years, has been reduced to little more than titular leader whom many residents blame for city's downfall; legislative action since Republicans won control of Congress in 1994 has shifted his powers to financial control board created by Congress to correct decades of inefficiency in city government; photos (M)
